HOPKINS BALL TOSSERS
SUCCUMB IN TENTH
INNING.
Poor Playing Aids Virginia in Becoming Victor in Extra Inning Contest.
Knecht Pitches Well for VarBand Proves
sity.
Added Attraction.

An error by Grace in the ninth
and poor base running by Strouse
the tenth were largely instrumental in' bringing about Hopkins'
defeat last Saturday at the hands of
the University of Virginia, to the
tune of 10 to 9. With the score tied,
two down and the bases filled in the
, ninth stanza; the Hopkins secondsacker let go of Dunn's grounder
and, before the final out had been
made, three Virginians had crossed
the plate.
Hopkins came back in her half
of the ninth and hits by Wood,
Grace, Hayter and' Sharretts enabled the home team to tie up the
count. The Southerners profited by
Owing's wildness in the tenth,
placing two men on the sacks by

FRATERNITY FRESHMEN TO
HOLD SMOKER.
Will Be Given in Barn on May 6. Plan
Sponsored by Sigma Chi Beta
Honorary Fraternity.

On the evening of May 6 a smoker will be held ,at the "Barn" by
the freshmen of the nine fraternities on the campus. The idea for
this movement was brought about
thro.igh the efforts of the Sigma
Chi Beta Honorary interfraternity society. It is the first time that
such a freshman affair has ever
been undertaken, but it looks as
though it will .be a great success,
and it will undoubtedly do much to
bring about a closer'relation among
the freshmen of the various fraternities.
Some forty-five men are expected to be present at the gathering
and the committee in charge is arranging a very attractive program
for the evening. Besides plenty of
cigarettes and music for all, there
will be a number of special stunts
gotten off by each delegation. The
committee will also have plenty of
refreshments on hand.

BALTIMORE, rob., MAY 3, 1921
ANNUAL TRIANGULAR DEBATE ENDS IN TIE.
Question Not Balanced Fairly As in All
Cases Affirmative Team Won
Contest.

The annual triangular debate between Hopkins, North Carolina and
Washington and Lee resulted in a
tie, the affirmative teams of each
college being defeated. That there
was little argument to the negative
side of the question, "Resolved,
That the United States government
should adopt a policy of further
material restriction of immigration," seemed to, be the opinion of
the presiding, judge at Washington
and Lee, when he complimented the
Hopkins negative team upon the
technical skill with which they presented a bad argument.
The Hopkins affirmative team,
composed of Dorsey, Watkins and
Parker Williams, defeated Washing and Lee's negative team at
Chapel Hill, N. C., at the same time
that Adolphus ,Emmart and Albert
Dimond lost to the North Carolina
team at Lexington. At Homewood
the Washington and Lee affirmative representatives defeated North
Carolina, thus making the contest
a tie.

Tryouts will be held on Wednesday afternoon in the Dramatic
Club's studio for the two playlets
to be put on at the next play night.
The authors of the plays and several of the cast of "Arms and the
Man" who will assist in the coaching will be on hand to try out all
the applicants and to assign the
best *to positions in the cast. It is
the earnest desire of the club that
a large number of men will come
not only to make the competition
more lively, but to give the officers
a chance to get a line on material
for next year's production.,Work
in these playlets will do much to
increase .chances of making the
production next year.

• TESTS SLATED FOR SATURDAY.
•

This Saturday both the lacrosse
and the baseball teams will engage
in very important contests.
The lacrosse squad will journey
to Hoboken to meet Stevens Institute. Stevens has always specialized in this sport and should -offer
our boys some opposition. Lehigh,
noted for "wielding a cruel stick",
downed the Hoboken engineers by
a 5-to-1 score, this spring, while
Swarthmore, who was defeated by
Mt: Washington, 9-2, three weeks
ago, outclassed them by a 8-2 score.
Followers of the sport pick the
Black and Blue to win without
serious difficulty.
The baseball team will pit its
strength against Navy in the second game of a doubleheader, Navy
playing University of West VirWith a fair

MUSICAL AND GLEE CLUBS TO
GIVE COMBINED CONCERTS
AND DANCE ON MAY 7.

On the evening of May 7 the
Musical and Glee Club will give
their annual concert at Homewood.
The performance will be given in
the Civil Engineering Hall, starting at 8 o'clock.• The manager of
the club has so arranged matters
that the price of admission has been
lowered to 50 cents and thus everyone is given an opportunity to attend. These tickets may be purchased from any member of the orIt is greatly feared
ganization.
that the number will have to be
limited, so it would be wise for
those wishing to attend to purchase their tickets immediately.
"Doug" Coulter and his assistants have arranged a very attractive program, with several special
features.
After the performance there will
be dancing until 12 o'clock. The
music will be furnished by the
University Orchestra.

After playing through, two periods of the hardest lacrosse seen
at Homewood Field for some tite,
the Hopkins-Syracuse game on Saturday ended in a 4-to-4 tie. It was
nearly seven o'clock when the game
ended and both coaches agreed that
it was too dark to play an extra
period, although both sides were
eager to get the final victory. The
long baseball game preceding, and
part of the second half was played
game was late starting, due to the
in a heavy dusk which made accurate pass work almost impossible.
Syracuse scored first after a long
period of play, but Hopkins quickly
retaliated and made three goals before their end of the half.
During the intermission the spectators were highly entertained by a
lacrosse contest by two leading girls'
schools in the city, as impersonated
by Hopkins men. The farce was
carried out with a great deal of success and received much applause.
The undergraduate band also aided
in the entertainment.
In the second half Syracuse came
back with the same rush which
characterized Hopkins' play in the
first half, and shot three goals in
succession. They seemed to have
solved our defense completely for
awhile, and by excellent stickwork
and hard, aggressive playing they
kept the ball in our territory for
the first half of the period. It was
here that Ed Wood, Zoller and
Benedict showed their ability, clearing out the field time after time and
*stopping what seemed to be sure
goals. A Syracuse man seemed to
be uncovered at all times and it
was only by the hardest playing
around goal that their fierce attack
was stopped. By the time Hopkins
had gotten together, lower goals by
Smith, Ross and Leydecker had

THE JOHNS ,HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 3, 1921
LANGELUTTIG AWARDED
TOQUEVILLE MEDAL
"France and Her Colonies," Subject of
His Address at Weekly Assembly. Four Men Entered This
Year in Annual Contest.

The Toqueville medal which has
been given annually since 1898 by
the Baron Pierre de Coubertin, of
Paris, and is awarded by the University to that student who shall
have delivered the best speech in a
contest in public speaking on some
phase of a general topic chosen
from the field of French history,
politics or literature of the nineteenth century, was won last
'Thursday before the general assembly by Albert Langeluttig.
The general topic chosen for
discussion was "France As a Colonial Power." Professor Chinard
who presided at the meeting, explained that the purpose of awarding the medal is not French propgandas, but is intended to foster a
better understanding of France and
French institutions.
C. I. T. Gould, the first speaker,
pointed out that while formerly
civilization had advanced largely
at the hands of Anglo-Saxons and
their tutelage of small nations, now
France, too, was using her full
share in intelligent colonization.
C. C. Marbury, the second
speaker, showed how hard the indifference of the French people
made it for France to become a
colonizing power. Many times
under the third republic the government was assisted by private initiative when funds were lacking.
A. E. Dimond discussed the
"Tariff Policy of France and Her
Colonies." This speaker devoted
his speech to the question as to
whether France governed her colonies for her own benefit or for
the good of the colony.
Albert Langeluttig, who spoke
last, is, of course, the hero of the
occasion. His topic was"France and
Her Colonies." The colonies are,
he said, "one of the most powerful
bands that unite the France of yesterday with the France of today.
Langeluttig's ir aterial seemed superior to that of the other speakers, and he spoke calmly, but emphasized his points in approved
fashion.
The judges were Prof. Lancaster, Dr. Burford Johnson and Dr.
Gruenbaum. While the judges
were deliberating. Prof. Chinard
told the students how enthusiastically the undergraduates of the U.
of Cal. come to the bi-weekly assemblies and urged that more interest be shown by the students at

THE RHODES SCHOLARSHIPS.

The Rhodes Trust, which has
under its care the awarding of the
Rhodes scholarships in the United
States, has issued a new memorandum containing a number of important changes.
Normally the stipend of the
scholarship is 300 pounds per year,
but scholars now receive in addition a bonus of 50 pounds, making
a total of 350 pounds per annum.
Scholarships are tenable for three
years and since two are assigned to
each state there is one year out of
every three in which there is no
election. In each of the other two
years one scholarship will be filled
if a suitable candidate applies.
Students applying for scholarships must be citizens of the United
States and unmarried; have passed
his nineteenth and not have passed

An innovation in the way of athletics has been inaugurated by
Coach Van Orman this spring by
having men out for. spring football
pi actice. It is Van Orman's idea
to teach the fundamentals of the
game—passing, charging, speed,
punting and other rudiments—thus
doing away with spending a great
deal of time on these things next
fall. By this method he hopes to
be able to go right into real work
as soon as the men reach camp and
thus be much farther advanced
than usual by the time of the fist
gaTe. Practice is held on Monday, Wednesday and Friday on the,
lower field and there have been
from ten to fifteen men out for
each practice. Several new men
from the Medical School have been
• over and have shown up very well.
This is an. unusual opportunity to
learn the game - as more personal
instruction is given than will be
possible next fall and at the same
time it gives an excellent chance to
keep in good physical trim. It is
hoped that all football men will
turn out and get the benefit of this
training.

PHI BETA KAPPA INITIATES EIGHT
HOPKINS MEN.

The new Phi Beta Kappa men
of the University were initiated
Thursday, April 21. The same
evening the Phi Beta Kappa banquet was held at the Hotel Emerson. The chief speaker was Dr.
Grandgent of Harvard whose subject was "Dante." The undergraduate members of the society initiated on the 21st were Bramble,
21; Heiner, '21; Kurrelmeyer, '21;
Ruark,'21; Halle, '21; Deems,'21;
Finesinger, '22, and Beard, '19.
Hullabaloo Offer Extended.

Although the time has expired in
which the Hullabaloo was to be offered at $3.50 a copy the offer will
be held open to any one who might
offer to sox.e member of the business staff a reasonable excuse for
his delay in subscribing. There
were, very probably, several who
felt that they would lack the required "kale" at the necessary time
but who have since discovered
some source, caution money, etc.,
by which they might subscribe.
Realizing what value the Hullabaloo will be to them in future
years, the board desires to give
every opportunity possible to the
delinquent ones.
As there are still several bills
unpaid, Business Manager Kennady requests that all contracts be
settled as soon as possible.
An effort is being made to have
the assembled copy. at the publishers in time to be unaffected by the
pressmen's strike. It is hoped that
the books will be ready for distribution at the Postoffice by June 1
at the latest.
DR. LIBBY ADDRESSES PREACHERS'
CLUB ON CHINA.

The Preachers' Club had a very
interesting meeting Monday night,
April 25. Dr. Libby, a missionary
doctor from Wuhu, China, gave an
informal talk on China and the
conditions there. Dr. Libby was
the only American doctor in the
native hospital where he worked
and had one native doctor and no
nurses to help him. The hospital
has forty beds, and with the dispensary, treats about fifty-two cases
daily. He hi.r.self often operated
three times a week.
At the next meeting to be held
Monday, May 9, the club will discuss their plans for next year.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 3, 1921

The News Letter Board takes
pleasure in announcing the recent
election to that body of William H.
Moore, '23, in the capacity of Junior Editor.
IS IT OUR FAULT OR NOT?

The sentiments expressed by Dr.
Gilbert Chinard, who was presidirg officer at the Toqueville Contest Thursday, should influence
every Hopkins man. He contrasted the enthusiasm displayed by students of the University of California at their bi-weekly assemblies,
with the apathy exhibited by us at
our own student gatherings. Although the News-Letter does not
agree with Dr. Chinard when he
says that this lack of interest is entirely the fault of the students
themselves, it does admit that there
are good grounds for his statement.
We have not supported .the assemblies the way we should; and
the worst of it is that it is very
largely the men who are leaders in

undergraduate life and men, above
all others, should be interested who
are most often absent. The whole
purpose of the assemblies was to
build up and foster college spirit.
If the leaders of the students are
absent.it is impossible for the assemblies to gain their objective.
It is true that as run this year
they have afforded little opportunity for the development of college spirit. Almost every hour has
been practically filled by lectures
of varying degree of interest. Upon
a few occasions, of which the
Adams Debate and Toqueville Contest are notable examples—the students have had the hour to themselves, but in the majority of instances the student announcements
have had to take the form of hurried, ill-prepared extempories. We
have had some exceedingly interesting lectures, but, after all, the
chief object in having an assembly
at all has been lost.
It is obvious that this state of affairs must be altered next year and
to that end we suggest that some
distinctive order of procedure be
adopted. Would it not be well to
have these gatherings under the
joint supervision of the-Dean and
Student Council, and let them arrange some program which would
be of interest to the students and
yet allow at least fifteen minutes
for student announcements, which
could then take the form of prepared addresses? We feel sure that
the Musical and Dramatic Clubs
would be glad to co-operate in providing entertainment. Occasional
addresses from prominent men on
topics of general interest outside
of the curriculum could be worked
in and time spent in the development of cheering and singing ability.
Would it not be a good thing for
Omicron Delta Kappa and the Student Council to investigate and suggest some means to make the student assemblies in the future more
truly a student gathering than they
have been in the past?

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
PASSES RUSHING AGREEMENT.
Engel Elected President and Wood Secretary for Next Year.

After the drawing up the rushthe interfraternity board has finally drawn up the rushing season
agreement for the coming year.
Since nearly all the fraternities represented on the board had widely
differing ideas it was extremely difficult to make a plan that would
suit every one. The best that could
be done was a co npromise arrangement that was not particularly unsatisfactory to any one chapter. The
agreement as finally adopted and
signed .by the delegates is as follows: "The rushing season for 1921
shall begin on October 31, one-half
an hour before the first class at the
university. From midnight of October 30th until the beginning of the
season there shall be no communication between any fraternity man
and any man in his first year of
residence at Johns Hopkins. The
purpose of inserting the period of
silence clause is to prevent entering
a freshman's house at an early hour
in the morning and remaining with
him until the beginning of the season which made it possible to discuss fraternity matters.
Afteh the drawing up the rushing agreement which completes the
work of the old interfraternity
board the officers for the coming
year were elected. Gibson Engel,
Kappa Alpha, was unanimously
elected president and R. M. Wood,
Beta Theta Pi, was chosen secretary. The new board will continue
tf) hold weekly meetings through- •
out the remainder of the term.
The past year has seen many important events in in terfraternity af•
fairs. Two new fraternities have
been admitted to the board, one of
them a chapter of Kappa Sigma, a
MATCH WITH WASHINGTON national organization, and the
other
AND LEE POSTPONED ON •
a local society, known as Beta Beta.

An error by Grace in the ninth
and poor base running by Strouse
the tenth were largely instrumental in' bringing about Hopkins'
defeat last Saturday at the hands of
the University of Virginia, to the
tune of 10 to 9. With the score tied,
two down and the bases filled in the
, ninth stanza; the Hopkins secondsacker let go of Dunn's grounder
and, before the final out had been
made, three Virginians had crossed
the plate.
Hopkins came back in her half
of the ninth and hits by Wood,
Grace, Hayter and' Sharretts enabled the home team to tie up the
count. The Southerners profited by
Owing's wildness in the tenth,
placing two men on the sacks by

FRATERNITY FRESHMEN TO
HOLD SMOKER.
Will Be Given in Barn on May 6. Plan
Sponsored by Sigma Chi Beta
Honorary Fraternity.

On the evening of May 6 a smoker will be held ,at the "Barn" by
the freshmen of the nine fraternities on the campus. The idea for
this movement was brought about
thro.igh the efforts of the Sigma
Chi Beta Honorary interfraternity society. It is the first time that
such a freshman affair has ever
been undertaken, but it looks as
though it will .be a great success,
and it will undoubtedly do much to
bring about a closer'relation among
the freshmen of the various fraternities.
Some forty-five men are expected to be present at the gathering
and the committee in charge is arranging a very attractive program
for the evening. Besides plenty of
cigarettes and music for all, there
will be a number of special stunts
gotten off by each delegation. The
committee will also have plenty of
refreshments on hand.

Cases Affirmative Team Won

The annual triangular debate between Hopkins, North Carolina and
Washington and Lee resulted in a
tie, the affirmative teams of each
college being defeated. That there
was little argument to the negative
side of the question, "Resolved,
That the United States government
should adopt a policy of further
material restriction of immigration," seemed to, be the opinion of
the presiding, judge at Washington
and Lee, when he complimented the
Hopkins negative team upon the
technical skill with which they presented a bad argument.
The Hopkins affirmative team,
composed of Dorsey, Watkins and
Parker Williams, defeated Washing and Lee's negative team at
Chapel Hill, N. C., at the same time
that Adolphus ,Emmart and Albert
Dimond lost to the North Carolina
team at Lexington. At Homewood
the Washington and Lee affirmative representatives defeated North
Carolina, thus making the contest
a tie.

MUSICAL AND GLEE CLUBS TO
GIVE COMBINED CONCERTS
AND DANCE ON MAY 7.

On the evening of May 7 the
Musical and Glee Club will give
their annual concert at Homewood.
The performance will be given in
the Civil Engineering Hall, starting at 8 o'clock.• The manager of
the club has so arranged matters
that the price of admission has been
lowered to 50 cents and thus everyone is given an opportunity to attend. These tickets may be purchased from any member of the orIt is greatly feared
ganization.
that the number will have to be
limited, so it would be wise for
those wishing to attend to purchase their tickets immediately.
"Doug" Coulter and his assistants have arranged a very attractive program, with several special
features.
After the performance there will
be dancing until 12 o'clock. The
music will be furnished by the
University Orchestra.

After playing through, two periods of the hardest lacrosse seen
at Homewood Field for some tite,
the Hopkins-Syracuse game on Saturday ended in a 4-to-4 tie. It was
nearly seven o'clock when the game
ended and both coaches agreed that
it was too dark to play an extra
period, although both sides were
eager to get the final victory. The
long baseball game preceding, and
part of the second half was played
game was late starting, due to the
in a heavy dusk which made accurate pass work almost impossible.
Syracuse scored first after a long
period of play, but Hopkins quickly
retaliated and made three goals before their end of the half.
During the intermission the spectators were highly entertained by a
lacrosse contest by two leading girls'

THE JOHNS ,HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 3, 1921
LANGELUTTIG AWARDED
TOQUEVILLE MEDAL
"France and Her Colonies," Subject of
His Address at Weekly Assembly. Four Men Entered This
Year in Annual Contest.

The Toqueville medal which has
been given annually since 1898 by
the Baron Pierre de Coubertin, of
Paris, and is awarded by the University to that student who shall
have delivered the best speech in a
contest in public speaking on some
phase of a general topic chosen
from the field of French history,
politics or literature of the nineteenth century, was won last
'Thursday before the general assembly by Albert Langeluttig.
The general topic chosen for
discussion was "France As a Colonial Power." Professor Chinard
who presided at the meeting, explained that the purpose of awarding the medal is not French propgandas, but is intended to foster a
better understanding of France and
French institutions.
C. I. T. Gould, the first speaker,
pointed out that while formerly
civilization had advanced largely
at the hands of Anglo-Saxons and
their tutelage of small nations, now
France, too, was using her full
share in intelligent colonization.
C. C. Marbury, the second
speaker, showed how hard the indifference of the French people
made it for France to become a
colonizing power. Many times
under the third republic the government was assisted by private initiative when funds were lacking.
A. E. Dimond discussed the
"Tariff Policy of France and Her
Colonies." This speaker devoted
his speech to the question as to
whether France governed her colonies for her own benefit or for
the good of the colony.
Albert Langeluttig, who spoke
last, is, of course, the hero of the
occasion. His topic was"France and
Her Colonies." The colonies are,
he said, "one of the most powerful
bands that unite the France of yesterday with the France of today.
Langeluttig's ir aterial seemed superior to that of the other speakers, and he spoke calmly, but emphasized his points in approved
fashion.
The judges were Prof. Lancaster, Dr. Burford Johnson and Dr.
Gruenbaum. While the judges
were deliberating. Prof. Chinard
told the students how enthusiastically the undergraduates of the U.
of Cal. come to the bi-weekly assemblies and urged that more interest be shown by the students at

THE RHODES SCHOLARSHIPS.

The Rhodes Trust, which has
under its care the awarding of the
Rhodes scholarships in the United
States, has issued a new memorandum containing a number of important changes.
Normally the stipend of the
scholarship is 300 pounds per year,
but scholars now receive in addition a bonus of 50 pounds, making
a total of 350 pounds per annum.
Scholarships are tenable for three
years and since two are assigned to
each state there is one year out of
every three in which there is no
election. In each of the other two

An innovation in the way of athletics has been inaugurated by
Coach Van Orman this spring by
having men out for. spring football
pi actice. It is Van Orman's idea
to teach the fundamentals of the
game—passing, charging, speed,
punting and other rudiments—thus
doing away with spending a great
deal of time on these things next
fall. By this method he hopes to
be able to go right into real work
as soon as the men reach camp and
thus be much farther advanced
than usual by the time of the fist
gaTe. Practice is held on Monday, Wednesday and Friday on the,
lower field and there have been
from ten to fifteen men out for
each practice. Several new men
from the Medical School have been
• over and have shown up very well.
This is an. unusual opportunity to
learn the game - as more personal
instruction is given than will be
possible next fall and at the same
time it gives an excellent chance to
keep in good physical trim. It is
hoped that all football men will
turn out and get the benefit of this
training.

PHI BETA KAPPA INITIATES EIGHT
HOPKINS MEN.

The new Phi Beta Kappa men
of the University were initiated
Thursday, April 21. The same
evening the Phi Beta Kappa banquet was held at the Hotel Emerson. The chief speaker was Dr.
Grandgent of Harvard whose subject was "Dante." The undergraduate members of the society initiated on the 21st were Bramble,
21; Heiner, '21; Kurrelmeyer, '21;
Ruark,'21; Halle, '21; Deems,'21;
Finesinger, '22, and Beard, '19.
Hullabaloo Offer Extended.

Although the time has expired in
which the Hullabaloo was to be offered at $3.50 a copy the offer will
be held open to any one who might
offer to sox.e member of the business staff a reasonable excuse for
his delay in subscribing. There
were, very probably, several who
felt that they would lack the required "kale" at the necessary time
but who have since discovered
some source, caution money, etc.,
by which they might subscribe.
Realizing what value the Hullabaloo will be to them in future
years, the board desires to give
every opportunity possible to the
delinquent ones.
As there are still several bills
unpaid, Business Manager Kennady requests that all contracts be
settled as soon as possible.
An effort is being made to have
the assembled copy. at the publishers in time to be unaffected by the
pressmen's strike. It is hoped that
the books will be ready for distribution at the Postoffice by June 1
at the latest.
DR. LIBBY ADDRESSES PREACHERS'
CLUB ON CHINA.

The Preachers' Club had a very
interesting meeting Monday night,
April 25. Dr. Libby, a missionary
doctor from Wuhu, China, gave an
informal talk on China and the
conditions there. Dr. Libby was
the only American doctor in the
native hospital where he worked
and had one native doctor and no
nurses to help him. The hospital
has forty beds, and with the dispensary, treats about fifty-two cases
daily. He hi.r.self often operated
three times a week.
At the next meeting to be held
Monday, May 9, the club will discuss their plans for next year.

IS IT OUR FAULT OR NOT?

The sentiments expressed by Dr.
Gilbert Chinard, who was presidirg officer at the Toqueville Contest Thursday, should influence
every Hopkins man. He contrasted the enthusiasm displayed by students of the University of California at their bi-weekly assemblies,
with the apathy exhibited by us at
our own student gatherings. Although the News-Letter does not
agree with Dr. Chinard when he
says that this lack of interest is entirely the fault of the students
themselves, it does admit that there
are good grounds for his statement.
We have not supported .the assemblies the way we should; and
the worst of it is that it is very
largely the men who are leaders in

undergraduate life and men, above
all others, should be interested who
are most often absent. The whole
purpose of the assemblies was to
build up and foster college spirit.
If the leaders of the students are
absent.it is impossible for the assemblies to gain their objective.
It is true that as run this year
they have afforded little opportunity for the development of college spirit. Almost every hour has
been practically filled by lectures
of varying degree of interest. Upon
a few occasions, of which the
Adams Debate and Toqueville Contest are notable examples—the students have had the hour to themselves, but in the majority of instances the student announcements
have had to take the form of hurried, ill-prepared extempories. We
have had some exceedingly interesting lectures, but, after all, the
chief object in having an assembly
at all has been lost.
It is obvious that this state of affairs must be altered next year and
to that end we suggest that some
distinctive order of procedure be
adopted. Would it not be well to
have these gatherings under the
joint supervision of the-Dean and
Student Council, and let them arrange some program which would
be of interest to the students and
yet allow at least fifteen minutes
for student announcements, which
could then take the form of prepared addresses? We feel sure that
the Musical and Dramatic Clubs
would be glad to co-operate in providing entertainment. Occasional
addresses from prominent men on
topics of general interest outside
of the curriculum could be worked
in and time spent in the development of cheering and singing ability.
Would it not be a good thing for
Omicron Delta Kappa and the Student Council to investigate and suggest some means to make the student assemblies in the future more
truly a student gathering than they
have been in the past?

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
PASSES RUSHING AGREEMENT.
Engel Elected President and Wood Secretary for Next Year.

After the drawing up the rushthe interfraternity board has finally drawn up the rushing season
agreement for the coming year.
Since nearly all the fraternities represented on the board had widely
differing ideas it was extremely difficult to make a plan that would
suit every one. The best that could
be done was a co npromise arrangement that was not particularly unsatisfactory to any one chapter. The
agreement as finally adopted and
signed .by the delegates is as follows: "The rushing season for 1921
shall begin on October 31, one-half
an hour before the first class at the
university. From midnight of October 30th until the beginning of the
season there shall be no communication between any fraternity man
and any man in his first year of
residence at Johns Hopkins. The
purpose of inserting the period of
silence clause is to prevent entering
a freshman's house at an early hour
in the morning and remaining with
him until the beginning of the season which made it possible to discuss fraternity matters.
Afteh the drawing up the rushing agreement which completes the
work of the old interfraternity
board the officers for the coming
year were elected. Gibson Engel,
Kappa Alpha, was unanimously
elected president and R. M. Wood,
Beta Theta Pi, was chosen secretary. The new board will continue
tf) hold weekly meetings through- •
out the remainder of the term.
The past year has seen many important events in in terfraternity af•
fairs. Two new fraternities have
been admitted to the board, one of
them a chapter of Kappa Sigma, a
MATCH WITH WASHINGTON national organization, and the
other
AND LEE POSTPONED ON •
a local society, known as Beta Beta.

A Column in Which the Correspondents

All letters intended for publication
must be concise.

evidence of good faith will not be printed

The publication of a letter is not to be

THE NEWS-LETTER, which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

To the Editor of News-Letter:
Kindly permit me, through the
column of your paper, to thank the
honest gentleman who returned to
the Y. M. C. A., without giving his
name, the ring I lost. May more of
his kind come to Hopkins.
Yours truly,
Thomas F. Hubbard.

A further addition to the Constitution states that by the unanimous vote of the club any man
who has worked for the club may
be taken in. Hitherto a man had to
take a part in the main production
of over twenty-five lines or a smallen part in two productions or fulfiu certain qualifications if working

awarded by membership for showing great interest in promoting the
dramatic work who, however, for
some good reason, was unable to
meet the requirements in any other
way. The club will be very slow
to admit anyone under this clause.

Amid the admiring plaudits of a
crowd of some two hundred persons and the stirring strains of a
band from Camp Holabird, the R.
0. T. C. of this university gave a
review last Thursday in honor of
Mayor Broening. Everything went
off in fine fashion; colors flapped
in the breeze, hands were "cut
away", and the lines were straight
as an arrow. It was the first real
review of the year and the Mayor
Must certainly have been impressed
with the good showing that was
made.
After the review there was a
formal guard mount participated
in by the most efficient and experienced men in the unit. This, too,
went off like clockwork. A very
popular part of the afternoon's program was the fact that the unit
was dismissed at five o'clock instead of at six.

GRADUATE SCHOOL OF

BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION
A two-year course in business leading
to the degree of Master of Business Administration.
Open to college graduates.
Courses offered in the following fields:
Accounting,Business Law,Banking and
Finance,Marketing, Advertising, Retail
Store Problems, Sales Management,Industrial Management, Labor Problems,
Business Statistics, Foreign Trade,
Transportation, Lumbering, Office Organization.
Five graduates of Johns Hopkins
University have attended the School,
two during the present year.
The registration for 1921-22 is limited
to three hundred in the first year
courses. Applications after May 1st
should be accompanied by a certified
transcript of the college record.
